column1: 10;10;essay11.txt;http://www.essayforum.com/writing-feedback-3/arguementative-persuasive-essay-camping-9834/;Everyone Should Go Camping;"Camping can take on many definitions. Spending time camping is a great way to revitalize the lungs. The phrase ""city air"" often is thought as air that is polluted
column5: while ""country air"" is often used to describe clean

column1: Another great part about camping is being outside under the sun. The sun rays help the human body with the production of vitamin D. In fact
column2: other than popping a vitamin pill

column1: With the recent downturn of the economy

column3: sewer
column4: and electric. A stay in a condo in the same area will cost at least $645.00 for the week. A condo will cost the family $491 more than a campsite. That difference in price can make a camping trip a good possibility while keeping the overall costs down to a minimum.

column2: or into the Band Lands of South Dakota. Camping can also take place at a nearby state park. No matter where the campsite is

This is specifically when they are experiencing nature and the realization is made how much simpler life is when outside with nature. Returning to nature often allows campers to return to their true selves. It is this discovery that should be experienced by all.

column2: when allowed

column4: animal testing has helped to create safer drugs and medical products that would not be available without animal testing.

column2: some medical procedures that involve animals have been found to be lifesaving for humans. For instance

column5: have been used to save the lives of humans in desperate need of a transplant. Additionally

column1: Despite the potential benefits of using animals for human benefit

column1: ;Giving aid to poorer countries has more negative effects than positive effects.

column4: and instead is being used to line the pockets of those in power. This can lead to a further entrenchment of poverty and inequality
column5: as those who are already in power are able to use the aid money to further their own interests.

column2: the aid money is not tracked or monitored

column4: and instead is being misused or wasted. This can lead to a further entrenchment of poverty and inequality

column1: ;Advertising is a powerful tool that can be used to influence consumer behavior. It is used to create demand for products and services

column1: Despite the useful outcomes of equal gender enrollment
column2: there are also some drawbacks that must not be overlooked. For example
column3: some universities may not have the resources or capacity to handle an equally divided enrollment of male and female students. This could lead to overcrowding or an unbalanced student population
column4: leading to lower quality education. Furthermore
column5: certain disciplines may be dominated by males or females due to historical trends or cultural norms
column6: meaning that the pursuit of gender balance could result in an unrepresentative student body in those areas.

column2: a one size fits all approach to gender equality in higher education is not appropriate. Universities should strive for gender balance
column3: but the implementation of such policies should depend on the particular university and student body
column4: taking into account the specific needs and dynamics of each institution. Moreover
column5: there should be an emphasis on providing equal opportunity and encouraging a diverse student population
column6: rather than enforcing hard quotas on gender enrollment.

column1: ;The debate between traditional and modern games in developing children's skills has been ongoing for many years. Traditional games have been around for centuries and have been passed down through generations

column1: 66;66;essay67.txt;http://www.essayforum.com/writing-feedback-3/practice-attempt-creative-artists-28640/;Creative Artists;"Innovative artists bring enjoyment and inspiration to our sometimes tedious life; however

column1: ;The issue of giving mobile phones to the unemployed is a complex one
column2: and one that has been debated for many years. On one hand
column3: providing mobile phones to the unemployed could be seen as a way to help them stay connected to potential employers and job opportunities. On the other hand
column4: there are concerns that this could be seen as a form of welfare

column1: The primary argument in favor of giving mobile phones to the unemployed is that it would provide them with a tool to help them find employment. Mobile phones are a powerful tool for communication
column2: and they can be used to search for job postings
column3: apply for jobs
column4: and stay in touch with potential employers. Additionally
column5: mobile phones can be used to access online job training and other resources that can help people find employment. This could be especially beneficial for those who live in rural areas
column6: where access to job resources may be limited.

column2: there are also some valid concerns about giving mobile phones to the unemployed. For one
column3: there is the potential for people to become dependent on government assistance. If people are given a mobile phone
column4: they may become less motivated to actively seek employment
column5: as they may feel that they have all the resources they need to find a job. Additionally
column6: there is the potential for people to misuse the phones

column2: the decision of whether or not to give mobile phones to the unemployed should be made on a case-by-case basis. For those who live in rural areas and have limited access to job resources
column3: providing a mobile phone could be a great way to help them find employment. However
column4: for those who live in more urban areas
column5: it may be better to focus on providing job training and other resources that can help them find employment. Additionally
column6: it is important to ensure that those who are given mobile phones are using them responsibly and not relying on government assistance.";"The rising cost of living and the stagnation of wages has left many people without jobs feeling the financial pinch. Mobile phones can provide a valuable lifeline for the unemployed
column7: allowing them to keep in touch with potential employers and to access valuable resources such as job advice websites. This essay will discuss the merits of giving mobile phones to the unemployed and some of the practical measures needed to make such a scheme successful.

column1: The first argument in favour of giving mobile phones to the unemployed is that it could help reduce the cost of job searching. Many people without a job and a fixed income struggle to keep up with the cost of applying for jobs; travel expenses for interviews and the cost of printing CVs can add up quickly. A mobile phone could allow jobseekers to apply for and attend interviews without having to incur these costs. Mobile phones also allow jobseekers to keep up to date in the job market by receiving notifications of relevant job postings and staying in touch with potential employers. In an increasingly digital world
column2: having a mobile phone could give the unemployed a much-needed edge and increase their chances of finding meaningful employment.

column6: the scheme must ensure the safety and privacy of the users
